Modified Calibrations name to Unit conversions
Renamed "connected to" to "parent port" in connection table and related code

Added a UnitConversionBase class which handles order of magnitude conversions (eg to p,n,u,m,k,M,G,T SI-prefixes) automatically. Just make your conversion class a subclass of UniConversionBase and pass you conversion a 'magnitudes' dictionary key with the value containing a list of prefixes as strings (eg {'magnitudes':['k','G'],...})

Modified import profiler. You now call enable(threshold) and disable to turn it on and off.

And it doesn't have indentation issues due to not decrementing its depth counter
when exceptions were raised in imports (as often happens, although they are expected and caught)

message.raw:
Added set_file function to change which file is being logged to after original setup.

This is so that all threads can be included in logging, even when you don't know what the log file should be called yet. So you can call log() as early as you want in your program, and then call set_file when you know what you want to rename the log file to.
For example in analysis_subprocess, we would like the log files to be named after the analysis routines of each process, but we don't know what the routine is until after some inititialisation code which starts some threads. These threads won't be logged unless we call log() before starting them.

message.raw:
Removed all shared drive mounting and finding functionality. Now all this module does is convert paths from local paths to platform agnostic ones and vice versa.

So if programs send paths over the network, they first call shared_drive.path_to_agnostic on it, and when programs receive paths, they call path_to_local before attempting to access the file.

This process is performed manually in many of our programs, they will slowly be migrated to use the same module, as is neater.

message.raw:
get_prefix_linux only worked for locations mounted using gvfs in the home directory of the user running the script. Mounted location might not use gvfs (e.g. on distributions where gvfs isn't  used, and/or those using etc/fstab).
Implemented support for such mounts, used after checking existence/use of gvfs.
As this module returns the mount point of any mounted filesystem on Linux (using gvfs, /etc/fstab), consider rename of:
* module "shared_drive" to "mount_point" or "mountpoint"
* function "get_prefix" to "get_mount_point" or "get_mountpoint" or "get_mtpt"
Also added os.sep to output of get_prefix_win, such that:
os.path.join( get_prefix( some_mount ), some_directory) works on Windows and Linux.

* function "get_prefix" to "get_mount_point" or "get_mountpoint" or "get_mtpt"
Also added os.sep to output of get_prefix_win, such that:
os.path.join( get_prefix( some_mount ), some_directory) works on Windows and Linux.
summary.html:
get_prefix_linux only worked for locations mounted using gvfs in the home directory of the user running the script. Mounted location might not use gvfs (e.g. on distributions where gvfs isn't used, and/or those using etc/fstab).
Implemented support for such mounts, used after checking existence/use of gvfs.
As this module returns the mount point of any mounted filesystem on Linux (using gvfs, /etc/fstab), consider rename of:
module "shared_drive" to "mount_point" or "mountpoint"
 function "get_prefix" to "get_mount_point" or "get_mountpoint" or "get_mtpt"
Also added os.sep to output of get_prefix_win, such that:
os.path.join( get_prefix( some_mount ), some_directory) works on Windows and Linux.

message.raw:
Fixed memory leak with dialogs.

You should either:
* call dialog.setAttribute(Qt.WA_DeleteOnClose,True) if you don't need to access the dialog once the user closes the dialog, or
* call dialog.deleteLater() once you have finished with the dialog

If you do not, the memory will not be cleared properly and your application will likely crash randomly after the dialog is closed.

Fixed memory leak with dialogs.

You should either:
call dialog.setAttribute(Qt.WA_DeleteOnClose,True) if you don't need to access the dialog once the user closes the dialog, or
 call dialog.deleteLater() once you have finished with the dialog

If you do not, the memory will not be cleared properly and your application will likely crash randomly after the dialog is closed.

message.raw:
a (hopefully temporary) fix for bug #610.
This is in the h5_lock module, which is where I was hacking things onto h5py anyway. I've disabled the actual h5_locking for the moment, until I make a few changes to pythonlib to accomodate it, such as BLACS worker processes not holding the file open for minutes at a time while they program a device (I'm looking at you, novatech) when they could easily close the file prior to programming.

Added imports everywhere needed throughout pythonlib

message.raw:
refs #534 (BIAS can read the connection table h5 file location from here)

refs #546

Modified BLACS to use a new labconfig file located in C:\labconfig\<hostname>.ini

Note that you will need to configure the ini file, and place the connection table.py/.h5 and BLACS settings files in the correct places before starting BLACS or else you will run into undefined behaviour depending on which part you did not configure correctly.

You may also lose front panel state if you do not do it correctly!

Added required_params argument to LabConfig class instantiation so that an exception is raised if certain parameters are not defined in the config file that are required. Obviously does not check whether the paths actually point to useful files!!

message.raw:
Created a LabConfig class that will read/load data from an .ini file
The class maintains its internal state by watching the file for changes and reloading

We should implement file locking for the .ini file through this class eventually, to avoid race conditions between multiple programs (unlikely to be an issue since the contents of the file will not be updated very often!)

message.raw:
Added h5_lock, which wraps network-based locking around the opening and closing of hdf5 files. If files are opened in any mode other than read only ('r'), then a redis lock will be acquired whilst the file is open.
Usage:
import h5_lock
h5_lock.turn_locks_on('bec.physics.monash.edu.au') # redis server
import h5py
# away you go

import h5_lock
h5_lock.turn_locks_on('bec.physics.monash.edu.au') # redis server
import h5py

away you go

values.message:
Added h5_lock, which wraps network-based locking around the opening and closing of hdf5 files. If files are opened in any mode other than read only ('r'), then a redis lock will be acquired whilst the file is open.
Usage:
import h5_lock
h5_lock.turn_locks_on('bec.physics.monash.edu.au') # redis server
import h5py
# away you go

message.raw:
fixed bug in restoring modified times

we now check to see if files have been removed from the list of files to check, and remove those missing files from the list of modified times. This way if a files is removed from the list of files to check, and then readded, it won't show up as being modified if it happened to have been modified when we weren't monitoring it. I believe that this is the desired bahaviour!

message.raw:
Added a module for caching the location of imports. Use like so:

from filewatcher.modulebooster import enable
enable()

It tracks where imports were found and saves the locations to a file,
so that their location on the filesystem doesn't need to be looked up again.

message.raw:
Promoted the lock acquisition to happen at a higher level so that modulewatcher does not even *read* sys.modules unless it has the lock.
This is to work around a bug whereby h5py appears not to be threadsafe and is corrupting simultaneously running threads...but seeminly only when they do a dict.items() loop. Very strage.

message.raw:
Applied a fix for a bug whereby modulewatcher might unload modules whilst an import is in progress, leading to potential inconsistencies.
Now it holds the import lock whilst it modifies sys.modules.

Also added an attribute unloader_lock, which users should hold whenever they want to disable the automatic unloading of modules.

message.raw:
Applied an attempted workaround to what appears to be a python bug.

The modulewatcher.ModuleWatcher.check_and_unload function would crash sometimes if a garbage collection cycle was running at the same time
I am not sure which part of it specifically, as adding printlines seemed to decreas the probability of a collision.

The attempted workaround is to disable garbage collection and manually check once a cycle if garbage needs to be collected.

message.raw:
Fixed a rare bug where the first file in the list of files to watch was temporarily unavailable when getting the modified time but was available when checking if the path exists.

This bug may have occurred often, but if it was not the first file in the list of files, then it would have used the modified time for the previous file. No obvious error would have been reported, (file may have been shown to be modified) but it was still incorrect behaviour.

message.raw: Fixed a bug in ModuleWatcher where it wouldn't know about changes in sys.stderr and would print to the old stderr (which might not even exist anymore). On Linux if it doesn't exist no biggie, you just don't get the messages. In Windows, you get an IOError: invalid file descriptor. So ModuleWatcher just prints to sys.stderr now rather than keeping track of its own error stream.

message.raw: Modified how subprocesses pipe output to parent processes. No longer do parents need to filter the output of the children to see what is stdout and what is stderr and what's something else of interest. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.
